displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Healthcare Professional: …could you check and see if my insurance will cover it. Doctor: Yeah, no, no, absolutely. So sit tight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re gonna wait for S___. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The research nurse and then your appointment is as scheduled as per our normal follow-up. Okay? Patient: What is it six months,three months? Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months. Doctor: Three months with the blood test before. Patient: That’s right. Yeah, blood test before, two days before. Doctor: You got it. Patient: Boy was it was packed in here on Tuesday.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Do you want to do it in two months or three months? Do you have any preference? Patient: Well when am I going to see you again? Doctor: January would be reasonable. How about three months from now? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do it about a week or two before? If I see you in mid-January? Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. We don’t know where. We’re going to so many places. The ship is supposed to stop at Puerto Rico and St. Maarten. So I know those two are . We do a lot of traveling. We just want to get away for a few weeks and we stay in Florida for three weeks and come back. Doctor: Okay, so - Thank you. You like it?

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Because if you had uh advanced disease it’s better to take it out first and then give radiation therapy as opposed to getting radiation therapy and then doing surgery. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The surgery is much more difficult, the side effects are more prevalent - Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - in patients who’ve had radiation therapy followed by surgery. Patient: Because I know you said I was starting to get there. I didn’t get there right? Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. I was starting to get there. Doctor: Right. Patient: And you know what makes me so comfortable with you is when we first met you told me you went through it. Doctor: Um hmm.

Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal? Doctor: Well, I was gonna, I was gonna talk to you about that. Um… Patient: Right. Doctor: I think it it probably - some type of hormone therapy is probably gonna be in your near future. It might not be the immediate future, but I think sooner rather than later given that we’ve tried this sort of outside-the-box non-hormonal type of therapy and it hasn’t really you know worked as well as we had hoped, the next step I think given that the PSA is rising and given that this lymph node is increasing, I do happen to believe it’s prostate cancer would lead me to the conclusion that hormone therapy is probably the next best thing to do. Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. The only thing it would be doing is slowing down the progress of the, it would slow down the - Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions –

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, I I did want to speak to you about um a research study that we’re doing that I think would be a good fit for you and I wanted to give you some details about that. Patient: Mm-kay. Doctor: And then give you some time to uh look at some written information that I’ll give you to take home. And you can look at that with your sister and your great-niece and the three of you can decide together whether you think this might be good idea for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And um I just wanted to um write some notes down. And then after I write these notes, I’m going to give you some detailed information about the the clinical trials. So, if if you are not at J_____ H_____. If you were just seeing a medical oncologist without- private practice or community um then the next step for someone like you, where the cancer might be growing or progressing despite the Abiraterone- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example.

Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh, so what I could do is talk to the pharmacist about the Xtandi and just figure out what it’s going to cost us, and look into the trials to see, uh, if we would- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I don’t know. Are you interested in doing another trial? Or are you sort of, you did a trial, and you’re ready to-? Patient: Well, no. I mean, anything that, that might help me to survive. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I know. I know.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you got to see most of the things you wanted to see? Patient: I think we did. Family Member: Yeah. We did. It was nice. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: All right. Good. That’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, today, we’ve got to sort of talk about what next. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I just reviewed, again, all the scans from a month ago or so. So really what we see in you is all of the disease seems to be in the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you don’t have any really anything in lymph nodes, or liver, or lung, which is, you know, good and bad. Uh, the bad part of it is, you know, it’s hard to kind of get a good sense of how things work in the bone because the scans we do are, uh, mostly telling us new spots in the bone. But they, we can’t really measure things getting bigger or smaller. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Twenty-second, twenty-third. Doctor: Let’s see what he finds. Okay so… Patient: I hope he don’t find nothing.
DOC Well good point. (Laughs) Doctor: This is your copy of the chemo consent. Okay? Alright so go over and we’ll go ahead with your treatment and you got all your scripts then. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: Everything else went electronically other that what you have in your hand. Okay? Doctor: You cane is here. Don’t forget. Patient: Thank you very much and I hope you have a good day Dr.V. Healthcare Professional 1: You too. Have a good one.

Patient: No, up at, uh, Hospital A. I got it a couple of weeks ago, Lupron. Doctor: Do you ever chew tobacco or snuff? Patient: No. (softly) Doctor: Get a flu shot this year? Patient: I did. Doctor: Uh, do you have any sense as to when you did that? Patient: It was in September, late September. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Doin’ good! Doctor: Uh, what’s goin’ on? Jaw still troubling you? Patient: A little bit, yeah. It’s, it’s, uh, right, right in, um in here. Right here. And the teeth are a little bit sensitive, just in spots Doctor: Gotten better or gotten worse?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: So we’re gonna go back on this? Doctor: Yeah I just have to check with M___ and make sure it’s all legit through the protocol. Um… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …get you the, you know the pills if that’s the case and then we’re on our way. Patient: Mhmm. Okay. Good. Family Member: Sounds like a plan. Doctor: Okay. Anything else? Healthcare Professional: Nope, probably protocol. Doctor: Okay. Yep. Uh sit up here. Let me, let me start working on that. I’ll be right back because I want to know about the records. Family Member: Okay. Okay, thank you. Doctor: Yep, one second. Yep, you’re welcome.

Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So you’d come in in the morning and you’d get your CT scan and you’d have your bone scan. And two or three hours after the two scans are done you would see me and by that time you would have the results. Have the images on my computer to look at them and discuss the results with you. The other possibility is to do the scans at a local radiology facility and then to get the images with the CDs and have the reports, get them sent to me and have one brought to you physically. But you know like I said if you agree with me, is to do it here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it’s not too much of a hardship. Patient: Very good. If when and needed. Doctor: Yes. And again that might not be for another six to twelve months. It could be sooner, a bit later depending on how or if your PSA increases. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Okay so we’ve given you about twelve cycles, but the good thing is it has worked and has kept the cancer in check all this time. The other good thing is that I didn’t see any other new areas. So the lung, liver, none of those were involved. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So what I’m going to suggest is that we change to a different kind of chemotherapy. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the advantage is that you know this mass that is resistant to the current chemotherapy will hopefully… Patient: Do you think that, you think that… Doctor: Respond. Patient: Okay. Nah you can keep Dr. V____.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
